awd_titl_txt: Conforma Field Theory and Stringy Geometry
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Ilarion V. Melnikov at James Madison University. 

Quantum Field Theory is a powerful mathematical framework that bears on almost every aspect of contemporary physics. These include the spectacularly successful Standard Model of Particle Interactions, the quantum phenomena in exotic materials that hold out great promise for new technologies such as quantum computing or energy storage and transfer, as well as theories that aim to uncover the fundamental laws of nature, such as String Theory. There has been tremendous progress in Quantum Field Theory over the past thirty years, and many questions that seemed intractable have been given precise and incisive answers. This project will build on those results by tackling a number of timely questions in Quantum Field Theory within realms where many of the standard tools are misleading or inapplicable.  The project will also address questions in two-dimensional Quantum Field Theory, relevant both for the physics of exotic two-dimensional materials and for the emergent geometry of spacetime in String Theory. As a result, research in this area advances the national interest by promoting the progress of science in one of its most fundamental directions:   the discovery and understanding of new physical laws. This project will also have significant broader impacts. Crucially, it will involve undergraduate researchers, who will be given a unique opportunity to engage in theoretical physics research and have early exposure to the mathematical and physical ideas at the forefront of current explorations.  This research will also be interdisciplinary, bringing together collaborations of physicists and mathematicians, and it will be presented in public lectures to convey the exciting progress in and enthusiasm for research in theoretical physics. 

More technically, Professor Melnikov's work will explore foundational questions in conformal field theory and geometry in two-dimensional quantum field theory relevant to string compactification. In this setting powerful symmetries and constraints from spacetime geometry will help to give precise quantitative insights into strongly coupled quantum field theory and string propagation in non-trivial spacetimes. The project will address three concrete problems: (i) the characterization of obstructions to marginal deformations of supersymmetric conformal field theories and their relation to spacetime physics of the heterotic string; (ii) the identification of marginal deformations of conformal theories with local operators in asymptotically free gauge theories that reduce to the conformal theory in the low-energy limit;  and (iii) the discovery of new conformal theories that enlarge the landscape of string vacua.  It will bear on long-standing issues in stringy geometry and the mathematics and physics of (0,2) mirror symmetry --- a significant generalization of the mirror correspondence. The concrete lessons learned will also have wider applicability in low-dimensional quantum field theory at strong coupling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award was used to tackle a number of timely questions in string theory and quantum field theory.  The latter is a framework that is used to describe a vast range of physical phenomena, from the intricate structure of the Standard Model of particle physics, to the functioning of a superconductor, and the formation of cosmological structures that encodes the early history of the universe.  The former is a framework for a theory of quantum gravity that aims to explain the microscopic structure of our universe and describe the nature of spacetime.

String theory incorporates the structure of Einstein's General Relativity, and it is therefore not surprising that the geometry of spacetime plays an important role in the formulation of the theory.  Most of the research supported by this award was devoted to questions having to do with string propagation on very small spaces - more precisely, spaces whose size is small compared to the size of the string.  The quantiative tools that we use to study these questions come from the framework of quantum field theory.  The study of this "stringy geometry" has been an important area of research for more than thirty years, and it has revealed many unexpected features and brought genuinely new ideas both to the exploration of string theory and to quantum field theory.

One of the main outcomes of this work partially addresses an old question in the stringy geometry of so-called Calabi-Yau manifolds.  These spaces are ubiquitous in string theory and are intimately related to a class of quantum field theories known as (2,2) supersymmetric conformal field theories in two dimensions.  Insights from stringy geometry have enabled mathematicians and physicists to uncover deep and unexpected connections between pairs of distinct Calabi-Yau geometries related by "Mirror Symmetry."  These insights have also been used to quantitatively study strongly coupled quantum field theories - an active topic of cross-disciplinary research and broad applicability.  

Mirror Symmetry can be understood as a conjectured equivalence of different parameters that describe the geometry:  starting with a pair of equivalent theories X and Y,  a "complex structure" deformation of X is equivalent to a "complexified Kaehler" deformation of Y.  Although the conjecture is very well tested and some aspects of it are proven, the results are limited to a subset of deformations, known as "polynomial" and "toric" deformations.   We have given a more general description of the deformations in the corresponding quantum field theory without this limitation to special subsets.  In addition to addressing a long-standing question in Mirror Symmetry, our methods may also be useful for describing deformation spaces of other quantum field theories.

Another outcome of the research supported by this ward was a deeper understanding of a class of heterotic string theory solutions.  The heterotic string offers a particularly tractable way to construct possible string theory solutions that resemble the observed microscopic physics of our universe in some important qualitative ways.  When compared to other string-theoretic constructions of such vacua, the heterotic string is appealing because of its formulation in terms of two-dimensional quantum field theory.  A particular focus, motivated by supersymmetric spacetime particle physics, is on (0,2) superconformal theories in two dimensions. 

Besides their appearance in the heterotic string, the (0,2) theories show up in many areas of string theory and quantum field theory, and while simple in some ways, these two-dimensional theories nevertheless provide great challenges: any progress on this class of theories translates into a deeper understanding of quantum field theories in general. 

We tackled a particular class of (0,2) theories, the so-called Landau-Ginzburg models.  These are very well understood when specialized to the more restricted class of (2,2) theories, but the more general class has remained mysterious for almost thirty years.  We undertook its study with the aim of classifying the possible (0,2) Landau-Ginzburg theories that reduce at low energy to (0,2) superconformal theories relevant to the heterotic string.  Working with a team of undergraduate students, as well as senior collaborators, we found new and unexpected constraints on the combinatorics of the (0,2) Landau-Ginzburg theories that have the expected low energy limits.  These constraints resolved an initial puzzle, because without them it appeared that there were infinitely many possible (0,2) Landau-Ginzburg theories. 

Understanding and generalizing these constraints will be of great interest both for constructing possible heterotic geometries and for studying examples of strongly coupled quantum field theories with subtle low energy limits.  Our work presents concrete examples of such theories, and there should be generalizations of these ideas two theories in higher dimensions as well.   Developing these ideas further by both physicists and mathematicians will be a crucial step in taming the world of (0,2) theories and will have lessons for the general study of quantum field theory as well.
